name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. In view of the refugee movements, we are facing a historic test, which we can certainly only overcome together. With solidarity internally and with solidarity to the outside world. That is why we are voting immediately on an emergency measure to relocate 120 000 asylum seekers from Italy, Greece and Hungary to other EU Member States. However, we can only overcome the ongoing humanitarian crisis if we also think about the external dimension of the problem. The situation in Syria, but also and especially in Syria's neighbouring countries, is deteriorating. Every day, therefore, more people make the perilous journey to Europe. We all know that the conflict in Syria is now entering its fifth year. There is no political solution in sight. Violence has continued to explode in recent months. People who get away with their lives still lose their livelihoods and their livelihoods and their homes. More than half of the people in this country live in extreme poverty, and also those four million registered Syrians who, thanks to the admirable generosity of their neighbours in Jordan, Lebanon and Turkey, have found refuge, live, or better survive, in difficult circumstances. This is quite simply because the host countries, especially Jordan and Lebanon, are reaching their limits, and also those aid workers who continue to assist the most needy in Syria and neighbouring countries in the most difficult circumstances are reaching their limits. The UNHCR is running out of money. Many of you have met Mr Guterres here this week. But, ladies and gentlemen, we cannot abandon our fellow Members, the aid workers and, above all, the UNHCR! The Madad Fund was established in December 2014 to provide basic services for refugees on the ground and to assist the host countries. Just two days ago in this House, Mrs Mogherini reminded us in this House that EUR 4 billion should flow from this fund. So far, however, ladies and gentlemen, only EUR 5 million has been contributed to the EUR 41 million from the EU budget from Germany and eur 3 million from Italy.  That is why, as President-in-Office of the Council, I have asked Prime Minister Bettel, as President-in-Office of the Council, in a letter relating to our resolution last week, to ensure that the outstanding funds are finally paid. (Applause) At the same time, I also call on the Commission to allocate all available funds from the EU budget to aid, particularly in Lebanon, Jordan, Syria, where possible, and Turkey.  Ladies and gentlemen, if we do not manage to do that, we will have many more problems than we already have today. Our credibility also depends on whether the money we make available to these countries is actually paid. I would therefore like to thank you for your support. I will publish this letter. And I have asked Mr Bettel, in the event that there should be an extraordinary European Council next week, to ask the Heads of State or Government to pay these funds immediately. (Applause)

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the We are in an exceptional political situation and Europe is facing major challenges. That is why today is the special sitting, which my group supports. Hence the important signal we are giving today that Europe is capable of delivering, especially the European institutions. Today we are going to give the signal of solidarity in Europe, and I support your position on the part of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats to give the signal of solidarity to the outside world as well. However, I would also like to say on my group that today's signal is only the first step. We also need other questions. We need to talk about the issue of safe third countries, about the control of external borders and also about the repatriation of those who have been rejected. That is part of the package, a clear European response. Today, as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, we want to send a signal that Europe is ready to act, and that is why we support the proposals that you have made.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Socialist Group is briefly convinced that today Parliament will give a strong signal of solidarity and attention to refugees, but also to European citizens. We support your letter, we agree with the spirit and the request to the Council and the Commission.  I was saying, Mr President, that we agree with your letter, the request that we also make to the Commission and the Council to mobilise these resources immediately in order to support action against refugees in Jordan, Lebanon and Turkey. I would like to take this opportunity to address, on behalf of my entire group, a great deal of thanks to all the volunteers and non-governmental organisations who are engaging in these hours with passion, love and great competence, showing great generosity.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank you for this initiative. Yesterday, in the debate with Mr Timmermans, we already raised this question of a lack of funding by the European Union. So we can fully support this. I do not understand how, when the European Union has foreseen in its budget a number of billions to give and to fund the UN directly, only a few million has been transferred after such a crisis. So we can give our support to the initiative, and I hope that the whole of the plenary can do so, though there may be some exceptions on the right.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, before speaking, I would like to invite those who are agitated here on the benches to show a modicum of respect for the expression of their colleagues. Of course, I would also like to support the proposal. I come to my point of order. For a moment, let me express myself. The point of order is that, Mr President, we are going to adopt an emergency text today. I would like to stress, on behalf of my group, that if the Council were to make substantial changes to the Commission's proposal, I would insist that this Parliament and the rights of this Parliament be respected. In other words, that this Parliament be consulted again. It was a point of order, gentlemen, and instead of vociferously, I invite you first to listen. All right?

name: Ashley FOX
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, earlier you said that you wanted us to help the most needy – and my Group would agree with you – but the most needy are not those who have the wealth, the health and the ability to walk from Syria to the borders of Europe. The most needy are those in the refugee camps of Turkey and Lebanon. So my Group will vote against this proposal because we do not think that opening the gates of Europe to anyone that can get to the frontier is the right method of helping them. We also think it is wrong, as a matter of principle, that the European Union orders – or, in your words, forces – Member States to accept people into their countries against their will. (Applause from the right)

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, although we believe that this resolution is not enough and we agree that there is a major humanitarian crisis, that there is war and that the European Union must contribute to all institutions in order to achieve peace in the region, we nevertheless consider it unacceptable for some Member States to close their borders today and not to see this great humanitarian crisis. We will support this proposal. We have to move from words to deeds. There are thousands of people who urgently need help, as well as member states such as Italy, Hungary and Greece. That is why, despite the fact that we are asking for more, despite the fact that we want to have a comprehensive political management of the refugee issue, we will nevertheless vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the UNHCR says there are currently 59 million displaced people in the world. Clearly, voting for this resolution today – for this legislation today – sends a message that actually Europe is prepared to accept limitless numbers of people. That, actually, is politically and physically impossible. Would it not be better, and more intelligent, for us to think about what the 1951 Geneva Convention and definition of a genuine refugee is? It is a person or persons who, as a result of their race, religion, political beliefs or orientation, are directly in fear of persecution. If we were, as Member States, to apply that and to help genuine refugees, we would take the support of our public with us. Opening up the door to countless millions, encouraging an exodus of biblical proportions and directly contributing towards the profits of the traffickers, hence leading to more people drowning in the Mediterranean, does not make sense.  (Applause from the right)

name: David BORRELLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the EFDD Group does not have a clear vision for this. The Italian delegation in this house strongly supports your request. We are convinced that Europe must make Europe, and three nations cannot be left alone to face this emergency.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the I consider it an inadmissible intervention for you, in your capacity as President, to express an opinion to the House here, while, on the other hand, a debate on such an important decision is not considered possible. We have sought to hold a debate on this important item on the agenda, and we are now in a situation where sham parliamentarianism and randomness of the debate are taking place, where people who raise their hands may or may not be able to speak. They are damaging to European parliamentarianism if it is not possible to hold a proper debate on such an important issue. And I can only appeal to everyone, apart from all the political views that are represented here, that we also respect the dignity of the House accordingly, that we allow a debate on important decisions and that we do not have a sham debate with Hauruck decisions, which is in fact not one, while in reality you are harming the House. In terms of content, I would also like to say that precisely what is being decided today is to divide the wave of refugees across Europe with urgency, is something that leads to massive resistance – also in this House – and also massively contradicts the principle of the sovereignty of the individual states. Rather, we should seek a solution as soon as possible that goes in the direction of helping the people on their home continent, and not impose on countries here with decisions things that are not shared by the people of Europe.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, the world is faced with a refugee crisis – Mr Farage is absolutely right in pointing to that – which will be with us for years to come. We will need to face the immediate crisis if we are – if we want to be – in a position to tackle the more structural crisis. We are challenged today as Europeans, on a political level, on a humanitarian level and – I would even say – on a moral level. Are we capable of providing solutions that are realistic, that are in compliance with our legal obligations but – most of all – that are in compliance with our souls? I want to say today, on behalf of the Commission, that we are very grateful to the European Parliament for understanding the urgency of the matter. We are very grateful to the President of the European Parliament for taking matters in hand and offering the possibility of having a vote today so that both institutions, under the leadership of the European Parliament, can say to Member States and the Council that the moment to act is now. The moment to act is on the basis of our humanitarian principles. We are not advocating the opening of all borders, but we are advocating staying in touch with our souls and not saying to people who flee from war and persecution, ‘You should stay away from Europe’s shores’.  (Applause) We need to act now and I do bow before this Parliament for taking the political responsibility to vote today. (Sustained applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Thank you, Mr Timmermans. Ladies and gentlemen! All the political groups have been given the floor briefly. I think it was clear that the overwhelming majority expressed their support for this letter by calling on Mr Bettel to pay out the funds for the camps in Jordan, Lebanon and Turkey without delay. Thank you again for that!

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: We shall now proceed to the vote on the Council's decision to introduce provisional measures in the field of international protection in favour of Italy, Greece and Hungary. I have a number of amendments from the EFDD Group on the decision. The EFDD Group has tabled a number of amendments of a negative nature. You will see straight away that the EFDD Group has asked for exactly the opposite in the draft legislative resolution. So don't be surprised. You will see this group on both the list of for and on the rejection list.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal to relocate 120 000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece (since Hungary has refused to benefit from the mechanism) because it is an urgent and necessary measure given the situation that the refugee crisis has produced in those countries and through the EU as a whole. It is a proposal that represents a significant increase from the 40,000 re-locations we voted on on 9 September. In addition, I voted in favour because I would like to send a strong message to the Council of Ministers for Justice and Home Office which will meet on 22 September to approve this second emergency mechanism at once. Given the seriousness of the EU's situation in the refugee crisis, I think it is important that the European citizens, we represent, perceive that the European Parliament is complying with its obligations quickly and that it is doing its job.  I would like to say that my support comes without prejudice to the position that Parliament will subsequently have to take in codecision on the Commission's proposal to establish a permanent relocation mechanism for crisis cases.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. This Resolution is born from a proposal from the European Commission which is wholy inadequate. According to the text of that text, an attempt is made to address the situation of 62% of asylum seekers within European borders, ignoring the remaining percentage and persons at the borders or on the way, and without indicating how the selection will be made. It also envisages a strengthening of the work of the Frontex agency, which we oppose for its role in the armour of European borders whose violent consequences we have seen these days, and will devote some of the money to expulsion processes. We understand that public money cannot be devoted to this life-threatening violation of the people who are returned to a country from which they have fled, whether by reason of war or persecution, whether by hunger or misery. This is a measure adopted as a face-washing in the face of social pressure caused by the situation created by European border-closing policies. Since we cannot support this continuing migration and border policy, we abstained in the vote.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ The entire principle of how the European Union is dealing with the migrant crisis is wrong and counterproductive. It will lead to more suffering, not less. EU refugee quotas are the wrong way to go about handling this situation. I supported various amendments to this resolution to mitigate its impact, but voted against the final Commission proposal and legislative resolution.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to address the refugee crisis in the EU more quickly and effectively. I support the decision to allocate 120 000 tonnes of aid to the Union over the next two years. persons seeking international protection. Frontex rapid border intervention teams and refugee reception centres must be deployed at sensitive EU border points. The EU must decide unanimously how to stop conflicts in war zones in order to achieve lasting peace and stability.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I supported this Council Decision for consistency with my previous votes and interventions. Today's result in the vote is further a sign of this House's commitment to a feasible, lasting and, above all, humane solution to the refugee crisis. I would like to require Member States to unlock the budget as soon as possible so that the necessary measures are put in place.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This text on the Council's decision to introduce interim measures on international protection for Italy, Greece and Hungary is to allow 120,000 "migrants" to be relocated to other European countries from the three countries mentioned above. This solution is not viable in the short term or in the long term, since it will shift the costs to other Member States which can no longer afford to take in new immigrants and will therefore also allow the arrival of ever more immigrants attracted by the windfall of such policies. Instead, the EU should stand firm, as is Australia, and finally abolish Schengen as Mrs Merkel now advocates in Germany by controlling its borders, even though it was delighted two weeks ago to welcome 800,000 new immigrants. In France, we have 7 million unemployed, 10 million poor and 1.5 million households waiting for social housing. Faced with this, we are being asked to take in (in addition to the usual immigration) 24,000 more refugees when the situation simply no longer allows it. So I naturally voted against that decision.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The extraordinary process that led to this hasty vote today is a clear example of the lack of democracy in this Europe and the continued exploitation that the left is fuelling with regard to the issue of migration. I am very much in favour of the principle of the distribution of migrants in quotas and I am in favour of their redistribution among the Member States. This decision, however, deals with the problem of immigration in a completely superficial way: suffice it to say that Europe not only does not distinguish between economic migrants and refugees, but that in dealing with the central issue of relocation, it will not take into account the arrivals of illegal immigrants prior to its entry into force. In short, Europe will not take account of almost all the landings in 2015 and therefore does not introduce the certainty of returns. For all these reasons, I was unable to support this text with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal to relocate 120 000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece (since Hungary has refused to benefit from the mechanism) because it is an urgent and necessary measure given the situation that the refugee crisis has produced in those countries and through the EU as a whole. It is a proposal that represents a significant increase from the 40,000 re-locations we voted on on 9 September.  In addition, I voted in favour because I would like to send a strong message to the Council of Ministers for Justice and Home Office which will meet on 22 September to approve this second emergency mechanism at once. Given the seriousness of the EU's situation in the refugee crisis, I think it is important that the European citizens, we represent, perceive that the European Parliament is complying with its obligations quickly and that it is doing its job.  I would like to say that my support comes without prejudice to the position that Parliament will subsequently have to take in codecision on the Commission's proposal to establish a permanent relocation mechanism for crisis cases.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal for a Council decision establishing provisional measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy, Greece and Hungary. Parliament welcomes the Council's decision to redistribute refugees under a scheme established by the Commission, taking into account country indicators such as GDP, population, unemployment rate, previous number of asylum seekers and resettled refugees. Due to its geographical location and conflicts in the immediate neighbourhood of the region, the conflicts that will still make these countries more vulnerable than other Member States in the near future will continue to flow into their territories.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I am pleased that we have supported the Commission's proposal, as we have shown that the EU helps its members when they face the problem of the European dimension. It is also about funding measures to take in and resettle refugees in order to relieve the border states in which they enter. This news is also important for Croatia, as the Hungarian refugee wall has been redirected to Eastern Slavonia and Syrmia. I am proud of my Slavonians and the way they welcomed these unfortunate people, unlike Orban, who also announces walls towards Croatia. I expect the Commission to help Croatia, because we will need help.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this text because I believe that solidarity is one of the fundamental principles not only of the European Union, but of European civilisation as a whole. I believe that the time has come for the Member States to realise the situation that the whole continent is facing and to begin to assume their responsibilities, sharing fairly the effort needed to deal with the situation.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. Italy, Greece and Hungary are completely overwhelmed by the influx of illegal migrants. In the face of this unprecedented migration crisis, the President of the European Parliament, Martin Schulz, has found nothing better than to call an emergency vote on the implementation of the relocation mechanism, including distributing more than 120,000 migrants in the other Member States of the Union or charging the recalcitrant States a fine equivalent to 0.002% of their GDP. Already, the various reception policies amount to more than 780 million euros, and this amount will only increase in the coming months, given the air appeal generated by these irresponsible decisions.  Scandalised by the voting procedure imposed on the schlague by the President of the European Parliament as well as by the financial support reserved for the reception of thousands of illegal immigrants, I obviously voted against this legislative motion, unlike the UMP/LR, centrists, environmentalists and socialists who voted for or abstained.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The decision is unacceptable and does not seem to want to solve the problem of uncontrolled immigration into Europe. I voted against a palliative that will not actually lighten the immigration burden in Italy and will act as a sounding board for new waves of migration. It should be noted that the 'democratic' President, Mr Schulz, rejected without explanation a resolution by my group expressing our clear direction.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal to relocate 120 000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece (since Hungary has refused to benefit from the mechanism) because it is an urgent and necessary measure given the situation that the refugee crisis has produced in those countries and through the EU as a whole. It is a proposal that represents a significant increase from the 40,000 re-locations we voted on on 9 September.  In addition, I voted in favour because I would like to send a strong message to the Council of Ministers for Justice and Home Office which will meet on 22 September to approve this second emergency mechanism at once. Given the seriousness of the EU's situation in the refugee crisis, I think it is important that the European citizens, we represent, perceive that the European Parliament is complying with its obligations quickly and that it is doing its job.  I would like to say that my support comes without prejudice to the position that Parliament will subsequently have to take in codecision on the Commission's proposal to establish a permanent relocation mechanism for crisis cases.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The Commission and the Council have consulted the European Parliament urgently on interim measures to relocate 120,000 refugees from Italy, Greece and Hungary. These three countries alone do not have to deal with the migratory pressure that the European Union is currently under. We must show solidarity and act quickly in the face of this situation, which is getting worse by the day. Member States must establish as soon as possible a concrete action plan to respond to this emergency, but also to avoid similar crises in the future. Jean-Claude Juncker's approach is very commendable in this sense. I voted in favour of this resolution. At the same time, I welcome the Council's recent decision to effectively relocate these 120,000 refugees.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. This report contained important provisions on the relocation of 120 000 persons. However, it is predicted that the Council will  make substantial changes to the proposal. At this point, the European Parliament will use its prerogative to ask for reconsultation given the substantial changes. Which means that my group, GUE-NGL, will be able to work on strengthening the Commission proposal through the tabling of  number of key amendments.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this proposal, which relocates 120 000 people from Greece, Hungary and Italy to other EU Member States, as I believe that it only serves to encourage further mass movement into the EU, thus possibly causing a further humanitarian crisis in both the Mediterranean and across the Sahara desert.   The definition of ‘international protection’ was not stipulated as in the 1951 Geneva Convention, but rather as an EU definition based on a separate directive.  This will force Member States to take an allocation of people – or if they try to opt out, they will be obliged to pay 0.002% of their GDP to the EU.  Furthermore, EU taxpayers will pay EUR 6 000 per person to the allocated country and EUR 500 per person to Greece, Italy and Hungary. As the EU enjoys freedom of movement, without border checks within the Schengen area, there is nothing to stop refugees from illegally travelling to many other EU Member States. The estimated budget cost is EUR 780 000.  Thankfully, the UK enjoys a separate opt-out under Protocol 21.  However, the UK will still be affected due to people trying to enter, thus exacerbating this humanitarian crisis further.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Council Decision as cooperation and solidarity between the Member States is the basis of the European Union and represents everything we stand for. Responsibility needs to be shared among the Member States in times like this and we should not leave the burden to fall on Italy, Greece and Hungary but help them deal with the common crisis. These measures are the first steps towards a binding, permanent distribution mechanism between every Member State.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted to make the urgent proposal to relocate 120,000 asylum seekers from Italy, Greece and Hungary to other EU Member States. The European Commission's proposal provides for a further 120,000 asylum seekers to be transferred from Italy (15,600), Greece (50,400) and Hungary (54,000).

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Council decision on the imposition of interim measures in favour of Italy, Greece and Hungary. Article 78(3) TFEI provides for an emergency response system to situations characterised by a sudden influx of third-country nationals. These measures are temporary and exceptional in nature. In addition, the Annex to the European Agenda on Migration, adopted on 13 May 2015, sets out well-defined criteria for the redistribution and relocation of persons in need of international protection: GDP, unemployment rate, past number of asylum seekers and resettled refugees. The Mediterranean Sea and the Balkans have seen an intensification of the migration situation in recent months, with around 140 thousand people, mostly from Syria, Eritrea and Afghanistan, who will be relocated to other European countries. Italy received about 40,000 asylum applications, an increase of 27% compared to 2014. Temporary measures in favour of Italy, Greece and Hungary have also been called for by the UNHCR and numerous NGOs.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. – In the emergency vote on the European Commission's proposal for a migration relational, I did not support Parliament's decision or the Commission's proposal in its present form. It is not a lack of solidarity. We are ready to take part in the solution, but the migration crisis cannot be solved only within the EU. The reception and distribution of refugees by quotas in each Member State does not solve the current crisis. After all, the wave of migration can continue for years. Of course, we must help those who are being persecuted politically, because it is our duty. But the solution is not to move the middle class there to Europe if there is a crisis somewhere in the world. Europe cannot do this indefinitely, but we are also depriving the societies concerned of the most mobile and trained. One of the keys to a long-term solution is stability in countries of origin and transit. The EU can provide assistance and support for this.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, convened in extraordinary session, overwhelmingly approved the European Commission's urgent proposal to activate a second mechanism for the relocation of migrants. The proposed emergency scheme provides for the redistribution of 120,000 asylum seekers from all Member States and benefits the countries most affected by the refugee crisis, namely Italy, Greece and Hungary. I fully support this decision, which finally provides, if approved by the Council, for a fair and fairer distribution of the burden among the States, increasing the operational and financial support of the European Union. This effort strengthens internal solidarity and will be essential in order to alleviate the pressure that now falls too far on the frontline countries. Today's vote delivers a clear message to national governments, demanding that they too now play their part, just as quickly as the European Parliament, to find shared and coordinated solutions to an unprecedented crisis.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this proposal of relocating 120 000 people from Greece, Italy and Hungary to other Member States as it will only serve to encourage another mass movement of people into Europe, which will inevitably lead to another humanitarian crisis in the Mediterranean.  The definition of ‘international protection’ was not stipulated as in the 1951 Geneva Convention, but rather an EU definition based on a separate directive. It will force Member States to take an allocation of people – or if they try to opt out they will have to pay 0.002% of their GDP to the EU. On top of this the EU (taxpayers) will pay EUR 6 000 per person to the allocated country and EUR 500 per person to Greece, Italy and Hungary. As the EU has freedom of movement and no border checks internally in many Member States, there is nothing stopping any of these people simply leaving that country and travelling to other countries illegally. The estimated budgetary cost for this is EUR 780 000 000. Thankfully the UK has a separate opt-out (Protocol 21); however, it will still affect the UK due to the movement of people trying to enter and of course encourage another humanitarian crisis.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 The extraordinary vote we held on 17 September is a precedent in the way the European Parliament operates and defeats the democratic principles of the institution and once again proved that the Social Democrats and christian Democrats are leading a common policy.  After the European Council did not decide on mandatory quotas for the reallocation of asylum seekers residing in Greece, Italy and Hungary, the President took a unilateral decision to put the Commission proposal to a vote. Thus, the European Parliament took a decision without discussing the proposal in its parliamentary committee and without being able to make any additions. I am firmly against the way the decision was made. I am also firmly opposed to quotas because they are a temporary solution to the problem and, if it works, will continue to be applied. First it was 40,000, now it's 120,000, the next wave will probably be even bigger. Under the dictatorship of the Social Democrats and the Christian Democrats, we will again be obliged to accept another quota of refugees. Distribution is not the solution to the problem, but on the contrary – a clear and loud invitation for even more refugees and illegal immigrants. The decision taken by the EP is the beginning of the end of the European Union.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 Today, the European Parliament voted in an emergency procedure on the European Commission's proposal for a migration re relationalisation, which would make Hungary a front country. This text is unacceptable to the Hungarian People's Party Delegation in this form, so I did not vote in favour of Parliament's decision or the Commission's proposal in its present form. Although Hungary does not shy away from negotiating an asylum mechanism to resolve the situation, it does not wish to become a front country. The European Commission has made the second relational proposal without consultation with the Hungarian Government, which would make Hungary a beneficiary, in addition to Greece and Italy, compared to the first. This is a trap, since it would not help Hungary, but would partially transfer the role and burden of Greece to it, forced to set up a so-called hotspot where refugee applications are accepted, processed and refugees distributed among the various Member States. Hungary state of transit, its classification as a front state is unacceptable to ask the Hungarian Government without prior consultation. This does not mean that Hungary does not wish to be involved in the development of a future mechanism under negotiation, but that he does not wish to be included in the beneficiary pillar alongside Greece.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has a matrix that imposes the defence of human dignity without any restriction. Human dignity is inalienable. The value of solidarity must be practiced. Member States must put aside national selfishness and work on a common solution to solve this problem. It is urgent to act with a united and common approach. I therefore voted in favour of the proposal for the emergency relocation of 120,000 asylum seekers from Italy, Greece and Hungary to other Member States. We must do everything to save human lives and welcome. But we have to solve the problem at the source. To this end, it will be necessary to increase the instruments, programmes and funds that contribute to the development of the countries of origin. The search for a peace solution for these territories is mandatory. I hope that the European Union, at this difficult time, will put into practice the values of solidarity, equality and fraternity.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal to relocate 120 000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece (since Hungary has refused to benefit from the mechanism) because it is an urgent and necessary measure given the situation that the refugee crisis has produced in those countries and through the EU as a whole. It is a proposal that represents a significant increase from the 40,000 re-locations we voted on on 9 September.  In addition, I voted in favour because I would like to send a strong message to the Council of Ministers for Justice and Home Office which will meet on 22 September to approve this second emergency mechanism at once. Given the seriousness of the EU's situation in the refugee crisis, I think it is important that the European citizens, we represent, perceive that the European Parliament is complying with its obligations quickly and that it is doing its job.  I would like to say that my support comes without prejudice to the position that Parliament will subsequently have to take in codecision on the Commission's proposal to establish a permanent relocation mechanism for crisis cases.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. The developments of recent weeks unmask the hypocrisy of the speech on an alleged EU humanitarian response to the refugee crisis. These developments leave the inhuman nature of that answer to the naked, which is the nature of the European Union itself. What has been sold to the peoples of Europe as an area of progress and development, peace, solidarity and respect for human rights, reveals to us, in the face of general horror, its true nature. Walls and barbed wire erected and dogs cast against those fleeing war and hunger; detention camps where everything is lacking, starting with the dignity denied to refugees. This Commission proposal falls short of what would be needed and contains aspects of which we disagree. However, it is imperative that at least the limited support provided for here can be used for refugees who will be relocated – from Italy, Greece and Hungary – in other Member States. And that this can be done now, with the manifestly urgent nature that the situation on the ground imposes. That is why we are voting in favour of this proposal, without introducing amendments which could delay the process of its adoption. But unfortunately, even this meagre support will probably be blocked in the Council.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I have clearly spoken out against any redistribution of migrants between Member States on the basis of quotas. In this particular vote, I expressed my position against the mechanism for the compulsory reassure of refugees. The European Union must find concrete measures to deal with this situation and must not narrow the whole debate down to mandatory quotas that are not its solution.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the Council's decision to introduce interim measures in the field of international protection in favour of Italy, Greece and Hungary. This text is out of reality, creates more problems and does not solve anyone, and most importantly it is all about the money that the host Countries will receive.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 Today, the European Parliament voted in an emergency procedure on the European Commission's proposal for a migration re relationalisation, which would make Hungary a front country. This text is unacceptable to the Hungarian People's Party Delegation in this form, so I did not vote in favour of Parliament's decision or the Commission's proposal in its present form. Although Hungary does not shy away from negotiating an asylum mechanism to resolve the situation, it does not wish to become a front country. The European Commission has made the second relational proposal without consultation with the Hungarian Government, which would make Hungary a beneficiary, in addition to Greece and Italy, compared to the first. This is a trap, since it would not help Hungary, but would partially transfer the role and burden of Greece to it, forced to set up a so-called hotspot where refugee applications are accepted, processed and refugees distributed among the various Member States. Hungary state of transit, its classification as a front state is unacceptable to ask the Hungarian Government without prior consultation. This does not mean that Hungary does not wish to be involved in the development of a future mechanism under negotiation, but that he does not wish to be included in the beneficiary pillar alongside Greece.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal to relocate 120 000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece (since Hungary has refused to benefit from the mechanism) because it is an urgent and necessary measure given the situation that the refugee crisis has produced in those countries and through the EU as a whole. It is a proposal that represents a significant increase from the 40,000 re-locations we voted on on 9 September.  In addition, I voted in favour because I would like to send a strong message to the Council of Ministers for Justice and Home Office which will meet on 22 September to approve this second emergency mechanism at once. Given the seriousness of the EU's situation in the refugee crisis, I think it is important that the European citizens, we represent, perceive that the European Parliament is complying with its obligations quickly and that it is doing its job.  I would like to say that my support comes without prejudice to the position that Parliament will subsequently have to take in codecision on the Commission's proposal to establish a permanent relocation mechanism for crisis cases.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal to relocate 120 000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece (since Hungary has refused to benefit from the mechanism) because it is an urgent and necessary measure given the situation that the refugee crisis has produced in those countries and through the EU as a whole. It is a proposal that represents a significant increase from the 40,000 re-locations we voted on on 9 September.  In addition, I voted in favour because I would like to send a strong message to the Council of Ministers for Justice and Home Office which will meet on 22 September to approve this second emergency mechanism at once. Given the seriousness of the EU's situation in the refugee crisis, I think it is important that the European citizens, we represent, perceive that the European Parliament is complying with its obligations quickly and that it is doing its job.  I would like to say that my support comes without prejudice to the position that Parliament will subsequently have to take in codecision on the Commission's proposal to establish a permanent relocation mechanism for crisis cases.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the proposal for a Council Decision laying down provisional measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. Successive tragedies in the Mediterranean require short-term emergency action; in this regard, the Commission has put forward a mechanism to activate an emergency response for the reception of migrants in the EU. Following the dramatic increase in migrants during the summer of 2015, pressure on the European Commission has resulted in the European Commission increasing the number of people to relocate. We understand that the emergency mechanism will allow Parliament to raise an increase in the number of migrants who can be welcomed. We hope that the EU's position on this issue will be clear and isolate and marginalises the far-right's requests for migration, which seek the 'bunkerisation' of Europe and the consequent closure of borders. We understand that documents, in any case, need to delve into the EU's own responsibilities in widespread crises in third countries. Without this analysis of responsibilities it will be impossible to propose solutions at the height of the emergencies we live in.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my Labour party colleagues, I voted in favour of these measures because Europe needs a spirit of cooperation and a common approach right now.  What is currently happening is unprecedented and will require a completely new European approach, something that can only be achieved if all 28 Member States come together and agree on a plan of action. No one Member State can do this alone, nor should they have to. Working together, the EU can provide safety and protection to those in need, but this crisis is also an opportunity, a chance to demonstrate European cooperation, what we can achieve together and how effective we are as a bloc.  We have a moral duty to act; we must help these people fleeing torture and persecution. EU governments cannot allow the current chaos and tragedy to continue.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal to relocate 120 000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece (since Hungary has refused to benefit from the mechanism) because it is an urgent and necessary measure given the situation that the refugee crisis has produced in those countries and through the EU as a whole. It is a proposal that represents a significant increase from the 40,000 re-locations we voted on on 9 September.  In addition, I voted in favour because I would like to send a strong message to the Council of Ministers for Justice and Home Office which will meet on 22 September to approve this second emergency mechanism at once. Given the seriousness of the EU's situation in the refugee crisis, I think it is important that the European citizens, we represent, perceive that the European Parliament is complying with its obligations quickly and that it is doing its job.  I would like to say that my support comes without prejudice to the position that Parliament will subsequently have to take in codecision on the Commission's proposal to establish a permanent relocation mechanism for crisis cases.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report on the Council Decision establishing provisional measures of international protection for the benefit of Italy, Greece and Hungary. Fundamentally, the EU’s Member States need to work together to deal with refugees arriving in Europe. Solidarity and shared responsibility is crucial during this uneasy time. These provisional measures are only the first steps and permanent measures are needed. This crisis will not go away unless a fair migrant distribution system is implemented within the EU. It is important that asylum seekers should be given information about the country they will be relocated to, and their preferences taken into account; also their consent would be required.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal to relocate 120 000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece (since Hungary has refused to benefit from the mechanism) because it is an urgent and necessary measure given the situation that the refugee crisis has produced in those countries and through the EU as a whole. It is a proposal that represents a significant increase from the 40,000 re-locations we voted on on 9 September.  In addition, I voted in favour because I would like to send a strong message to the Council of Ministers for Justice and Home Office which will meet on 22 September to approve this second emergency mechanism at once. Given the seriousness of the EU's situation in the refugee crisis, I think it is important that the European citizens, we represent, perceive that the European Parliament is complying with its obligations quickly and that it is doing its job.  I would like to say that my support comes without prejudice to the position that Parliament will subsequently have to take in codecision on the Commission's proposal to establish a permanent relocation mechanism for crisis cases.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Council Decision on the imposition of interim measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Italy, Greece and Hungary on the basis that urgent and concrete measures are needed to provide an adequate and effective response to the refugee wave. These countries certainly need help. We are witnessing that other Member States, as well as Macedonia and Serbia, face major problems. Thousands of refugees have entered the Republic of Croatia, and therefore I believe that the European Commission needs to act swiftly by providing financial assistance to Union members, third countries and refugee camps in the Middle East. More than ever, communion and a coordinated approach to the crisis are needed.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal to relocate 120 000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece (since Hungary has refused to benefit from the mechanism) because it is an urgent and necessary measure given the situation that the refugee crisis has produced in those countries and through the EU as a whole. It is a proposal that represents a significant increase from the 40,000 re-locations we voted on on 9 September.  In addition, I voted in favour because I would like to send a strong message to the Council of Ministers for Justice and Home Office which will meet on 22 September to approve this second emergency mechanism at once. Given the seriousness of the EU's situation in the refugee crisis, I think it is important that the European citizens, we represent, perceive that the European Parliament is complying with its obligations quickly and that it is doing its job.  I would like to say that my support comes without prejudice to the position that Parliament will subsequently have to take in codecision on the Commission's proposal to establish a permanent relocation mechanism for crisis cases.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I have long disagreed with the proposals for the compulsory relocation of refugees within the Union states, as they do not provide real solutions to the current problems and threaten the political stability of the Union.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. A Europe-wide quota system and a lifting of the Dublin II Agreement will not help Europe in the face of the huge influx of refugees. On the contrary, the problems in the countries of origin must be resolved in a sustainable manner. Similarly, the people who are now fleeing – more than two-thirds of them young men – must have the opportunity to rebuild their homeland. Nor is the proposal aid ingesto to the overburdened authorities, which need more powers of access, faster procedural decisions and more staffing levels. I therefore reject this draft.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained in the European Parliament's vote on a resolution establishing the admission of 120 000 refugees from Italy, Greece and Hungary. I believe that all EU Member States should be involved in helping member states in difficulty today by receiving additional asylum seekers who have already arrived in those Member States and who need international protection. However, such assistance must be based on the principle of voluntaryity and not on compulsory quotas binding on Member States. Likewise, the EU's external borders have not been closed and strengthened, so there is a high risk that the flow of refugees will only increase and the number of people to be divided between Member States will continue to grow. The EU must set up and fund refugee reception points outside EU territory, such as Turkey, and develop a transparent and legal system so that war refugees can be admitted to EU Member States in a controlled manner. The European Union must finally address the causes, not the consequences.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Following the Council meeting on Monday and the lack of consensus – or urgency – in reaching majority agreement on an organised and compassionate response to the refugee crisis here in the EU, it is absolutely vital that Parliament speaks to this issue directly and immediately. Parliament’s backing in record time of the Commission’s 9 September proposal to relocate 120 000 asylum seekers sends a clear signal to EU home affairs ministers that it is high time to act and finally agree on this second emergency scheme. I applaud the European solidarity expressed by the House on the refugee crisis.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. After the failure of the Negotiations in the Council on the resettlement of 40 000 refugees in order to relieve the burden on the first host countries, the Commission came up with a new proposal and increased number of refugees. Over the next two years, 120,000 refugees will be distributed from Italy, Greece and Hungary to other countries.  Although I am convinced that the EU states should show solidarity with the heavily burdened countries in the current situation, I strongly condemn the action taken by the Commission and the President of Parliament to use the current migration crisis as an opportunity for further centralisation of the EU rather than to present a sustainable solution. I therefore rejected the Commission's proposal. First of all, existing agreements such as the Dublin Regulation must be respected. At the same time, we need a coherent approach as soon as possible, which takes a holistic approach to managing migratory flows to Europe.  The ALFA has presented such a concept entitled "Auxiliary culture instead of welcome culture". Among other things, ALFA calls in the short term for the reintroduction of border controls, the designation of other safe third countries in the Western Balkans, the conversion of cash benefits to benefits in kind for asylum seekers and the consistent collection of their biometric data. In the long term, in cooperation with other states, protection zones for refugees will be established, country sponsorships will be taken over and cooperation with third countries on the repatriation of rejected asylum seekers will be strengthened.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. – In light of the dramatic increase of refugee arrivals over the summer and the increased pressure put on the Commission for more solidarity, we clearly need to push for a more European solution. This is the reason I voted favourably, giving a political signal that we support the Commission’s proposal and are working hard in this direction on this multidimensional issue.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I abstained on Thursday on the proposal for a temporary distribution mechanism for refugees from Italy, Greece and Hungary. Solidarity with political refugees is of course necessary and the right to asylum is an irrefutable right. However, the introduction of binding quotas, the possibility of refugees challenging relocation decisions and a system of classification by asylum seekers of preference countries would encourage large-scale migration movements, creating an "air call" that European countries cannot cope with with dignity. In the absence of any common European asylum and immigration policy, in the absence of ever-strengthened controls at the external borders of the European Union, in the absence of effective treatment mechanisms for genuine asylum seekers and the fight against asylum fraud, imposing binding quotas for the reception of refugees seems to me to be premature and hasty to say the least.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. On behalf of the National Front MEPs, I strongly protest against the vote on Thursday 17 September on the Commission's new proposal to relocate 120,000 migrants across the European Union. The President of the Parliament, Mr Schulz, and the political groups who supported his proposal to hold this vote in haste were well aware that some Member States such as Hungary, the Czech Republic and Slovakia were firmly opposed to the Commission's plan. In wanting to apply the emergency procedure at all costs, Mr Schulz abused his power. He used Parliament as a means of pressuring Member States for protecting their borders. He held an emergency vote on Thursday, when Parliament was in session the day before. He refused a formal parliamentary review of the Commission's proposal. He also declared an amendment by the ENL group critical of him ineligible. All this is unworthy of a Parliament that claims to be democratic.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal to relocate 120 000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece (since Hungary has refused to benefit from the mechanism) because it is an urgent and necessary measure given the situation that the refugee crisis has produced in those countries and through the EU as a whole. It is a proposal that represents a significant increase from the 40,000 re-locations we voted on on 9 September.  In addition, I voted in favour because I would like to send a strong message to the Council of Ministers for Justice and Home Office which will meet on 22 September to approve this second emergency mechanism at once. Given the seriousness of the EU's situation in the refugee crisis, I think it is important that the European citizens, we represent, perceive that the European Parliament is complying with its obligations quickly and that it is doing its job.  I would like to say that my support comes without prejudice to the position that Parliament will subsequently have to take in codecision on the Commission's proposal to establish a permanent relocation mechanism for crisis cases.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The Commission proposes that 120 000 refugees from Italy, Greece and Hungary will be distributed to other countries over the next 2 years.  Although I am convinced that the EU states should show solidarity with the heavily burdened countries in the current situation, and I have agreed in Parliament to the resettlement of 40 000 refugees, it is nonsensical to provide for greater resettlement until the basic mechanisms of EU asylum policy have regained. Germany currently accepts twice as many asylum applications as would be provided for under the Dublin rules, while other EU states participate only below average in the common EU asylum policy. It is therefore necessary to respect existing agreements such as the Dublin Regulation. At the same time, we need a coherent approach as soon as possible, which takes a holistic approach to managing migratory flows to Europe.  ALFA has presented such a concept entitled "Auxiliary culture instead of welcome culture". Among other things, ALFA calls in the short term for the reintroduction of border controls, the designation of other safe third countries in the Western Balkans, the conversion from cash to in-kind benefits for asylum seekers and the consistent collection of their biometric data. In the long term, UN protection zones for refugees will be established, country sponsorships will be taken over and cooperation with third countries on the repatriation of rejected asylum seekers will be strengthened.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The situation with refugees is becoming more serious by the day, so unanimous agreement is needed immediately as the number of refugees grows drastically. The Commission's main messages call on Member States to be solidarity, to share responsibilities evenly and to stress that the borders of the European Union should remain protected under the rules of international agreements, but must not be closed, as this violates the values represented by the Union. I supported a Resolution of the European Parliament accepting the Commission's proposal to introduce interim measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Italy, Greece and Hungary. This is a clear message from Members of Parliament to the Council to convene a session as soon as possible so that Member States' ministers will accept the measures, show solidarity towards refugees and mutual unity. The proposal concerns 120,000 refugees fleeing conflict to european union border countries. By distributing responsibilities evenly, Croatia should accept 1 064 people. With the closure of the Hungarian-Serbian border, the refugees continued their journey to Western Europe through Croatia and the situation is worrying as some 15,000 refugees have entered in the first two days to which the responsible institutions were not ready.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. \u2012 The current European legal framework on asylum is extremely bad for countries at the Union's external land and sea borders. Under the basic principle of the Dublin system, these countries, including Bulgaria, have to deal with the ever-increasing mixed migration flow of asylum seekers and illegal economic immigrants on their own.  Long before today's crisis, I was among those who called for profound change and an overhaul of the very essence of this system. Today, it is now clear to all that a corrective mechanism is needed to jointly and severally distribute the burden from the first line countries to the interior of the Union. The European Commission has come up with proposals for mandatory quotas and guarantees that solidarity between Member States will not remain in good faith alone. I stand firmly behind this idea because it practically protects the Bulgarian interest and will protect Bulgaria for decades from the threat of sudden and mass incursion along our land border with Turkey. The European Parliament has shown that it can react responsibly and quickly at a critical time. By a majority of 67% MEPs approved the measures proposed just a week ago by the Commission. The Member States are now on the move, which within the Council must take the final decision.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament's record-breaking mobilisation of the vote is a political signal to the interior ministers of the EU Member States, who will meet again on Tuesday, 22 September, to try to agree on emergency measures to tackle the refugee crisis again after the 14 September failure. I voted in favour.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the Council decision to introduce interim measures in the field of international protection for Italy, Greece and Hungary, because this gives a European dimension to the migration-refugee problem facing Greece. However, measures are urgently needed such as: firstly, the repeal of the Dublin III Regulation which turns Greece into a warehouse of souls; secondly, the application of the distribution clause for all refugees and illegal immigrants at European Union level; thirdly, measures against Turkey which supports the slave trade circuits, as Hurriyet revealed on 29 May 2015; fourthly, a brave increase in European Union funds to Greece; , because the amounts provided are crumbs given the criticality of the situation; fifthly, the restoration of international peace in the Middle East.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. A redistribution of illegal immigrants over the heads of the Member States must be vehemently rejected. The cost of this, amounting to EUR 780 000 000, is intolerable. The decision is nothing more than another invitation to economic migrants. The decision is a completely misguided term for illegal immigrants. Member States should be allowed to choose their own way of dealing with illegal immigrants. I therefore rejected this decision.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it is crucial that the Union takes a closer step towards greater solidarity among Member States. These measures are a necessary point of departure towards a binding, permanent distribution mechanism between every Member State.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. In the face of the migration crisis, only an ambitious European solution will ensure a solidarity and sustainable management of the phenomenon. States such as Greece, Italy and Hungary alone cannot manage the entire migration flow. It is a collective responsibility. I am therefore pleased that the European Parliament has agreed to the establishment of a mechanism for the relocation of 120,000 migrants. The adoption of this dossier in the emergency procedure underlines the European Parliament's willingness to be reactive on this issue. This mechanism consolidates the mechanism that was recently adopted in the previous plenary, which aimed to relocate 40,000 asylum seekers from Greece and Italy. These mechanisms now respond in part to the emergency but can only be the first step towards a permanent European mechanism.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I support the Commission’s proposal for emergency action to relocate 120 000 asylum seekers from Italy, Greece and Hungary. It is time for the EU to finally show true ‪solidarity, collective ‪responsibility‬ and ‪unity‬ and to address the urgency of this situation without any further delay. With my vote, once again, I strongly call on Member States and governments to finally show true collective ownership and strong political leadership, and with concrete actions and specific measures to respond to the global refugee crisis.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 I firmly believe that the current refugee crisis can only be addressed through European cooperation and cooperation. This proposal for a decision is the beginning of this European cooperation, which was voted on in full unity by the European democratic left and right, with the support of the PP-Christian Democrats, left-wing, liberal and green factions. I was happy to join this democratic unity.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The European Union knows what is urgent when it comes to imposing disguised and massive economic immigration on peoples. Within days, MEPs had to vote on the so-called mechanism for relocating 120,000 refugees, i.e. illegal, in addition to the 40,000 already voted on 9 September. In practical terms, Member States will have to welcome these people according to a distribution key defined by the Commission. Less than ever, states are therefore free from their migration policies and have control of their borders with Schengen. This text is an illustration of the arrogance of Brussels which, not content with its blissful angelism in the face of the uncontrolled influx of pseudo-refugees, imposes on the peoples of Europe, who are suffering from austerity and the crisis, the reception of new economic migrants, who will weigh on social accounts and compete with them in the labour market. The elected representatives of the ENL group are therefore resolutely against this decision.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This vote is the occasion of a wonderful exercise in conformity by the European institutions, where the EPP and the Social Democrats, hand in hand, have called for a vote in favour of the Commission's proposal on the distribution of 120,000 new migrants. But why then have to divide these "migrants" as a burden since they remind us all day long that "immigration is a wealth"? Thus, according to the Commission's proposal, a total of 160,000 asylum seekers would be displaced from Italy, Greece and Hungary (which is just the beginning, given that several hundred thousand migrants are waiting to join the EU). Worse, this text supports the "compulsory distribution" of migrants between states, according to a key distribution to say the least despicable. At a time when EU countries are in crisis and in near-structural recession, this text proposes to pay 6,000 euros per relocated migrant. To paraphrase Rousseau, "such a Europeanist loves the Tartars, to be excused from loving his fellow citizens." For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted for the emergency proposal to relocate 120,000 asylum seekers from Italy, Greece and Hungary between the Member States of the European Union. We are delivering a response of support in record time to the European Commission's proposal of 9 September; it is a clear signal to the ministers of the Member States that they can finally act and agree on this second emergency plan. Europe must remain an area of solidarity while acting to better control its external borders and develop a coherent refugee policy.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I have not been able to vote calmly in favour of the Commission's proposal because, on the one hand, I believe that the material still needs to be amended and, on the other hand, the voting procedure, namely that the material to be voted on and the amendments to it have been made available to Members at the last minute, shows irresponsibility.  Of course, we know that time is of the essence and that now is the time to act. However, for this specific substance, it is a programme to be implemented over a period of 2 years to relocate refugees already living within the Union. Not a tenth of these are now in the countries listed to be helped, as they have long since moved on.  However, there is nothing to stop action at Member State level. In my opinion, the quota system is not the key issue on this subject, and I cannot therefore support it, but concrete steps to address the root of the problem. Everything must be done to stabilise the situation in the Middle East so that we can finally reach a truce. At the same time, we Europeans have a moral obligation to help those in trouble financially. EU Member States do have to reach into their pockets and support turkish, Jordanian and Iranian refugee camps through secure channels. It is also in our own interest, because if we do not, millions of people who are starving there will head for the EU.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 Such a Council decision cannot be accepted. First of all, the problem of reception and integration of refugees should not be addressed at EU level, but globally. This problem must be tackled by all the nations of the world. The rising wave of migration needs to be addressed with all political levers. First of all, we need to stop the business-to-business transport of illegal migrants to Europe and to work much more closely with the governments of African countries. Strict economic sanctions or other penalties cannot be imposed on Member States which, for objective reasons, are unable to participate in resettlement activities. Such regulation is flawed and incompatible with the sovereign rights of the Member States. In this context, I believe that there should be an exception which would give States the right not to participate, in whole or in part, in the transfer of applicants from a Member State.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ Solidarity is a key value of the EU. This value should find its way into EU action in order to collectively distribute the heavy weight of the refugee crisis. Such problems can only be addressed at the level of the Union – that is, together.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ At an extraordinary plenary session in Brussels, the European Parliament adopted a proposal to urgently redistribute 120,000 asylum seekers from Italy, Greece and Hungary to other Member States of the European Union due to the overload of the three countries. More than eleven thousand people have entered Croatia in just one day, and this number is increasing by the minute, and as many as eighty thousand refugees are expected to arrive at the Croatian border. The borders are not functioning as they should, entry into Croatia takes place uncontrollably and through illegal crossings, and we also testify that some of them do not want to stay in the safety of our reception centers, which puts before us all the question of whether they have hidden intentions. It has also been noted that there are those among refugees from Syria who come from areas not affected by war (such as Serbia and Kosovo). We have to make a distinction between war refugees and economic refugees. People who are really physically persecuted, who have been left homeless and left their country out of mere fear for their lives, those who have traveled the way they have really been the only way to stay alive, we must give such people security and assistance and I expect the European Commission to help Croatia financially in providing this assistance.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The Commission's proposal establishes a mechanism for distributing illegal immigrants in the various Member States without taking into account their will. Not only is it a clear attack on democracy, but it is also particularly stupid. Indeed, leaving un doubtless to meet deplorable reception conditions in countries that do not want them, these illegal immigrants will become illegal immigrants squared, fleeing the states where the Commission wanted to send them. Most of them know very well which country they want to go to and, if the dangers of the Mediterranean have not stopped them, it is difficult to see how the Commission's wishes would achieve this, especially since the dogma of free movement in the Schengen area is not even in question. Like the majority of French people, I do not want France to take in migrants as long as millions of poor and unemployed suffer every day. I further reject the Commission's outliers. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I support the council's proposed Decision to introduce interim measures in the area of international protection in order to redistribute refugees who have been staying in EU border countries for a long time between member states according to the proposed quotas and thus jointly assist those Member States most exposed to the increasing number of refugees who arrive every day due to their border position. I hope that the Commission will also take into account as soon as possible the changed routes of refugee movement, including Croatia, where thousands of migrants arrive every day, in order to apply equal access to those countries. The problem of refugees and migrants is a common European problem and the European Union should thus be set up in addressing it.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of this legislative resolution so that Parliament can give its full support to the Council's decision. I believe that it is essential to implement, in the short term, concrete action capable of alleviating and sharing the enormous effort that the Italian, Greek and Hungarian authorities are painstakingly carrying out in the management of this exceptional wave of migration; by applying the principle of solidarity, among the Member States, which is the building block of the EU.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the Council Decision establishing interim measures in the field of international protection in favour of Italy, Greece and Hungary, which comes with mandatory quotas for the redistribution of 120,000 refugees, in the final vote, in line with the position of the Czech Republic and in view of my longstanding view that mandatory quotas are inappropriate and ineffective. The proposal itself mentions the return of refugees relocated to one country if they go to a country other than that intended for them. This also confirms my view that the quota system will not be effective and refugees will continue to migrate to the Member States where they wish and where they have not been relocated. In the split vote, I supported the proposal to change the mandatory quotas to voluntary, but this did not pass.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The European Parliament adopted a resolution on the Council's decision to introduce interim measures on international protection for Italy, Greece and Hungary. However, I abstained on this text because some overly restrictive measures could undermine the stability of the Union. I am against mandatory and permanent quotas. First of all, I believe that the Union needs to rethink its migration policy.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this proposal of relocating 120 000 people from Greece, Italy and Hungary to other Member States as it will only serve to encourage another mass movement of people into Europe, which will inevitably lead to another humanitarian crisis in the Mediterranean. The definition of ‘international protection’ was not stipulated as in the 1951 Geneva Convention, but rather an EU definition based on a separate directive. It will force Member States to take an allocation of people – or if they try to opt out they will have to pay 0.002% of their GDP to the EU. On top of this the EU (taxpayers) will pay EUR 6 000 per person to the allocated country and EUR 500 per person to Greece, Italy and Hungary. As the EU has freedom of movement and no border checks internally in many Member States, there is nothing stopping any of these people simply leaving that country and travelling to other countries illegally. The estimated budgetary cost for this is EUR 780 000 000. Thankfully the UK has a separate opt-out (Protocol 21); however, it will still affect the UK due to the movement of people trying to enter and of course encourage another humanitarian crisis.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. Through this vote, which validates the new emergency relocation measures proposed by the Commission for 120,000 asylum seekers from Italy, Greece and Hungary, the European Parliament sends a strong message to the Member States. A determined call to urgently adopt realistic and ambitious solutions, respectful of our legal obligations and commitments to give full meaning to the right of asylum and the principle of non-refoulement. It is in no way to expect that the next meeting of interior ministers on 22 September will end in another failure. Inaction is an option to be banned; we no longer have time to divide ourselves. Although I regret the terms of this approval, in an expedited procedure which did not allow Parliament to look in detail at this essential issue, it was important to defend these mandatory solidarity measures and to put the Council in front of its responsibilities. If MEPs supported the Commission's proposal without amending it, this does not prejudge the position they will later adopt on the permanent and compulsory relocation mechanism, on which Parliament will co-decide on an equal footing with the Member States.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal to relocate 120 000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece (since Hungary has refused to benefit from the mechanism) because it is an urgent and necessary measure given the situation that the refugee crisis has produced in those countries and through the EU as a whole. It is a proposal that represents a significant increase from the 40,000 re-locations we voted on on 9 September.  In addition, I voted in favour because I would like to send a strong message to the Council of Ministers for Justice and Home Office which will meet on 22 September to approve this second emergency mechanism at once.
