Given the seriousness of the EU's situation in the refugee crisis, I think it is important that the European citizens, we represent, perceive that the European Parliament is complying with its obligations quickly and that it is doing its job.  I would like to say that my support comes without prejudice to the position that Parliament will subsequently have to take in codecision on the Commission's proposal to establish a permanent relocation mechanism for crisis cases.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The European Parliament voted today in favour of the European Commission's proposal to distribute 120,000 refugees in EU countries on a mandatory basis. The text proposes an emergency "relocation" plan for refugees currently in Italy, Greece and Hungary. Under the law, another 120,000 asylum seekers are reported to be displaced from Italy (15,600), Greece (50,400) and Hungary (54,000). Member States still divided on the issue are due to vote on the measure on 22 September, after failing to take a unanimous decision on the issue of distribution, as opposition from a minority of Eastern European states caused the failure of the extraordinary council of EU interior ministers last week in Brussels. Even if Parliament does not have the power to co-decision on this measure, its consultation was essential for a decision by the Council to be taken. That is why we used this vote today in an emergency procedure. Parliament's support sends a clear signal to the European home ministers that it is high time to act and finally agree on this second emergency plan.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the Council decision because I agree with the interim measures in the field of international protection in favour of Italy, Greece and Hungary which stipulate the various measures to be taken to deal with the migration and security emergency. The decision for a fairer and more balanced distribution of refugees between Member States is based on criteria such as GDP, population, unemployment rate and the number of refugees seeking political asylum. The temporary measures provide for the relocation of refugees from Italy, Greece and Hungary to other Member States – the 'Member States of relocation' – which will be subject to specific obligations that they will have to comply with.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Until I know the answer to the question of whether the proposed permanent relocation mechanism has a guarantee against abuse and a set upper limit and what this limit will be determined, I cannot vote for any of these proposals in accordance with the position of the Czech Government.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. This Resolution is born from a proposal from the European Commission which is wholy inadequate. According to the text of that text, an attempt is made to address the situation of 62% of asylum seekers within European borders, ignoring the remaining percentage and persons at the borders or on the way, and without indicating how the selection will be made. It also envisages a strengthening of the work of the Frontex agency, which we oppose for its role in the armour of European borders whose violent consequences we have seen these days, and will devote some of the money to expulsion processes. We understand that public money cannot be devoted to this life-threatening violation of the people who are returned to a country from which they have fled, whether by reason of war or persecution, whether by hunger or misery. This is a measure adopted as a face-washing in the face of social pressure caused by the situation created by European border-closing policies. Since we cannot support this continuing migration and border policy, we abstained in the vote.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 In many ways, the legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council decision on the introduction of temporary measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy, Greece and Hungary called for solidarity with people in need seeking refuge in Europe. Although the proposal took into account the cultural and social ties of the beneficiary country, as well as the necessary level of solidarity between Member States, the final objective of the document was to force mandatory quotas for the admission of refugees to the Member States. I therefore abstained in the vote on this resolution.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. After the failure of the Negotiations in the Council on the resettlement of 40 000 refugees in order to relieve the burden on the first host countries, the Commission came up with a new proposal and increased number of refugees. Over the next two years, 120,000 refugees will be distributed from Italy, Greece and Hungary to other countries.  Although I am convinced that the EU states should show solidarity with the heavily burdened countries in the current situation, I strongly condemn the action taken by the Commission and the President of Parliament to use the current migration crisis as an opportunity for further centralisation of the EU rather than to present a sustainable solution. I therefore rejected the Commission's proposal. First of all, existing agreements such as the Dublin Regulation must be respected. At the same time, we need a coherent approach as soon as possible, which takes a holistic approach to managing migratory flows to Europe.  The ALFA has presented such a concept entitled "Auxiliary culture instead of welcome culture". Among other things, ALFA calls in the short term for the reintroduction of border controls, the designation of other safe third countries in the Western Balkans, the conversion of cash benefits to benefits in kind for asylum seekers and the consistent collection of their biometric data. In the long term, in cooperation with other states, protection zones for refugees will be established, country sponsorships will be taken over and cooperation with third countries on the repatriation of rejected asylum seekers will be strengthened.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Written. 'Once again, the temporary mandatory dispersal plan does not meet our requirements. The lack of external border security is not being remedied and Europe remains on the brakes on the development of a national activation policy. The N-VA delegation voted against and at the same time marvels at the lack of ambition. The plan is completely unaffected by the existing flows towards Western Europe, because it does not affect the effective application of the existing rules of asylum and Schengen acquis. Improving reception conditions, developing streamlined procedures, pushing up return operations, and so on were initially a pas currency for solidarity with Italy, Greece and Hungary, but are now severely under-exposed. Even the so-called hotspots, in which EASO and Frontex would replace the unwilling Member States, were watered down. We now hope that the Council of Ministers will adopt a system that is more in line with the Statements of the European Council.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ The European Commission presented on 13 May 2015 a comprehensive European Agenda on Migration, highlighting on the one hand the urgent measures to be proposed by the Commission in response to the crisis situation in the Mediterranean and, on the other, the medium and long-term initiatives to be taken to provide structural solutions to better manage all aspects of migration. The situation at the borders of the eastern Mediterranean deteriorated dramatically in July and August 2015, when a figure of more than 137,000 illegal migrants entered Greece via Dodekanese and the northeastern Aegean Islands (especially Kos and Lesbos) was found. Equally, more than 42,000 illegal migrants arrived in Italy through the central Mediterranean, and 78,472 migrants entered Hungary across the Hungarian-Serbian border during the same period. I therefore support interim measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Italy, Greece and Hungary to enable them to effectively address the problems associated with the current large influx of third-country nationals in their territories, which is straining their asylum systems.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 Today, the European Parliament voted in an emergency procedure on the European Commission's proposal for a migration re relationalisation, which would make Hungary a front country. This text is unacceptable to the Hungarian People's Party Delegation in this form, so I did not vote in favour of Parliament's decision or the Commission's proposal in its present form. Although Hungary does not shy away from negotiating an asylum mechanism to resolve the situation, it does not wish to become a front country. The European Commission has made the second relational proposal without consultation with the Hungarian Government, which would make Hungary a beneficiary, in addition to Greece and Italy, compared to the first. This is a trap, since it would not help Hungary, but would partially transfer the role and burden of Greece to it, forced to set up a so-called hotspot where refugee applications are accepted, processed and distributed among the various Member States. Hungary state of transit, its classification as a front state is unacceptable to ask the Hungarian Government without prior consultation. This does not mean that Hungary does not wish to be involved in the development of a future mechanism under negotiation, but that he does not wish to be included in the beneficiary pillar alongside Greece.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this decision because, in the face of the refugee crisis, the Commission, among the European institutions, has finally prepared an urgent and substantive package of measures, which must be given strong political support from the EP. This includes the sharing of the burden of reception according to an agreed mandatory quota system, which I consider to be natural, since the whole functioning of the Union and the sharing of the resulting burdens and benefits are governed by rules and quotas jointly established on the basis of solidarity aspects. With my vote, I also wanted to say that I think it is intolerable that, in an urgent situation, our effective joint action, both humane and practical, seems to have failed again at Council level, because of the self-righteous domestic-tactical aspects of some Member States. It is regrettable that the most extreme example of this is provided by the Hungarian Government, whose measures, in addition to the exclusion and humiliation of refugees, are aimed at persecuting and punishing its own citizens who are trying to help them. I believe that it is time for the Union to create its own capacity and instruments against such unscrupulous behaviour in the Member States, which also makes joint European action impossible, and I trust that this decision is also a step in this direction on the refugee issue.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the proposed text. I do not recognize myself in this policy of European governments. In recent days, politicians have said they want to deprive refugees of certain rights or create special statutes for these migrants. I believe that these kinds of statements must be put to an end. It is out of the question to embark on this path, which would undermine our moral and legal duty to welcome these refugees who arrive at our country to escape the horror. In such a situation, the role of politics is not to stoke fears or to maintain fantasies, but to act according to the principles and values that underpin our rule of law. Europe must take its share of responsibility. People who fear for their lives should be allowed to apply for asylum in their country of origin, so that they do not put their lives at risk by crossing the Mediterranean in extremely dangerous conditions. In any case, there will be no viable solution without solidarity and without humanity. I will continue to fight for these values to be taken into account and respected!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the proposal of the Commission to relocate 120 000 people from Greece, Italy and Hungary. Indeed, as I underline consistently, I am opposed to the quotas system proposed by the Commission. Refugees can not be forced to go to a particular country if they do not want to stay there.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I object to the urgent procedure of this procedure, since I do not hold it transparent enough; does not allow for the possibility of committee discussion, reporting, and time for constructive negotiation between political groups. Also, I do not support the system of forced realisation, because I believe that voluntary access is the only one appropriate in such cases. Europe has a moral duty to help the afflicted crying out for refuge fleeing the horrors of war. Our leading role in the world must not only be based on economic and scientific achievements, but also on a higher degree of humanity and empathy. That's where I believe we all agree. But I am very dissatisfied with the messages that the Union is sending at the moment because I have a feeling that certain political circles are using this appalling situation to promote their populist policies. They are obviously unable to understand that we would help refugees the most if we used all our military-diplomatic capacities and stopped the war in their homeland and then gave them a hand in building the kind of society they once had. Everything else is just a firefighting measure that, due to the increased security threat in these chaotic conditions, can very easily backfire on both refugees and their European hosts.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. It is also not fair for Member States to tackle the refugee problem themselves. I have supported the even distribution of refugees across Member States in a spirit of solidarity and responsibility. I believe that solidarity and responsibility go hand in hand. That is why it is very important that all of us who take decisions to deal with the migrant problem also be aware of our responsibility for our common future.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against it because I fundamentally disagree with the mandatory refugee quotas for Member States. This is not a solution to the migration problem and cannot work in practice either.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. After the failure of the Council negotiations on the resettlement of 40 000 refugees in order to relieve the burden on the first host countries, the Commission's new proposal had to increase the number of refugees. Over the next two years, an additional 120,000 refugees will be distributed from Italy, Greece and Hungary to other countries. Again, these figures are not appropriate in view of real migration. Although I am convinced that the EU states should show solidarity with the heavily burdened countries in the current situation, I strongly condemn the action taken by the Commission and the President of Parliament to use the current migration crisis as an opportunity for further centralisation of the EU. Moreover, it is inappropriate for Mrs Merkel to set a line on her own and without consultation with the other states and then push it through by the EU against legitimate opposition. I therefore rejected the Commission's proposal. If key European systems such as Dublin and Schengen have obviously failed, short-term measures must be taken to address acute difficulties. This includes, for example, the immediate and comprehensive reintroduction of border controls. We then need a consensual European solution to reform the foundations of migration policy. Specifically, we have called for the establishment of safe zones in the regions of origin of migrants.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the proposal for a Council Decision laying down provisional measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. Successive tragedies in the Mediterranean, which do not seem to have a near end, require short-term emergency action; in this regard, the Commission has put forward a mechanism to activate an emergency response for the reception of migrants in the EU. Following the dramatic increase in migrants during the summer of 2015, pressure on the European Commission has resulted in the European Commission increasing the number of people to be relocated within the EU. We understand that the emergency mechanism will allow Parliament to raise an increase in the number of migrants who can be welcomed into the territory. We hope that the EU's position on this issue will be clear and isolate and marginalises the far-right's requests for migration, which aim, on its agenda, for Europe's 'bunkerisation' and the consequent closure of borders.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Commission proposal for the relocation among EU Member States of 120 000 refugees. It is just a small step in tackling the worrying refugee crisis that Europe is facing, but at least it is a sign that Europe is finally taking action. The measures envisaged by the Council decision will serve to alleviate the huge burden of refugees that Italy, Hungary and Greece have had to sustain in the past months. It is positive that the European Parliament has given a strong signal that solidarity and cooperation among Member States is crucial at this point. This non-binding decision by the European Parliament has now given the green light to the Council to work on the final agreement on the relocation scheme.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. In the face of europe's migration crisis, such measures need to be taken in those countries that are experiencing the greatest impact of migration flows. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this decision.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal to relocate 120 000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece (since Hungary has refused to benefit from the mechanism) because it is an urgent and necessary measure given the situation that the refugee crisis has produced in those countries and through the EU as a whole. It is a proposal that represents a significant increase from the 40,000 re-locations we voted on on 9 September.  In addition, I voted in favour because I would like to send a strong message to the Council of Ministers for Justice and Home Office which will meet on 22 September to approve this second emergency mechanism at once. Given the seriousness of the EU's situation in the refugee crisis, I think it is important that the European citizens, we represent, perceive that the European Parliament is complying with its obligations quickly and that it is doing its job.  I would like to say that my support comes without prejudice to the position that Parliament will subsequently have to take in codecision on the Commission's proposal to establish a permanent relocation mechanism for crisis cases.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to support the Council's decision to relocate on a voluntary basis, over the next two years, 40,000 refugees from Italy and Greece, directly affected by the refugee crisis. This decision is not yet a permanent and binding measure to ensure that all the countries of the Union contribute in a coordinated way to providing the necessary protection to those fleeing conflict and persecution, nor is it a sufficient and effective solution to the refugee crisis and to the exceptional migratory flows that must be addressed by acting on the root causes of conflicts and instability. , also through the change of our trade policies. It cannot be denied, however, that this is a necessary first step towards the recognition of the principles of solidarity and cooperation between European states, and therefore towards overcoming the Dublin Regulation, to which we have strongly opposed. That is why I voted in favour of this decision.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of the operational development of the Juncker Plan (distributing 120 000 additional refugees), with clear agreements for the countries concerned and with the guarantee of rights and obligations for asylum seekers. Should the situation in another Member State escalate, the redistribution will be reviewed.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The refugee crisis eloquently demonstrates the hypocrisy of the speech on a supposed EU humanitarian response. These developments leave the inhuman nature of that answer to the naked, which is the nature of the European Union itself. Thus, a whole laborious image of a Europe as a space of progress and development, peace, solidarity and respect for human rights falls apart.  In the face of general horror, with the walls and barbed wire erected and dogs thrown at those fleeing war and hunger, the detention camps, where everything is lacking to begin with the dignity denied to refugees, we can only find this cry of indignation at the icy reaction of a Europe that is depressing an urgent solution for these thousands of human beings who are victims of EU imperialism. , the United States and NATO. The Commission falls short of what would be necessary and contains aspects that confront the values of human dignity. However, it is imperative that at least the limited support provided for here can be used for refugees. That is why we are voting in favour of this proposal, without introducing amendments which could delay the process of its adoption. But unfortunately, even this meagre support will probably be blocked in the Council.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. A redistribution of illegal immigrants over the heads of the Member States must be vehemently rejected. The cost of this, amounting to EUR 780 000 000, is intolerable. The decision is nothing more than another invitation to economic migrants. The decision is a completely misguided term for illegal immigrants. Member States should be allowed to choose their own way of dealing with illegal immigrants. I therefore rejected this decision.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. Almost all migrants want to go to Germany; they were invited by Chancellor Merkel. Other Member States, however, are very realistic about their capacity for integration and reject the unconditional reception of migrants. That is why there can be no mandatory EU quotas for the distribution of refugees. That is why I voted against the proposal. On the other hand, it is not acceptable for the EU Parliament to use distribution keys to redistribute migrants, but it does not itself send a concrete signal to relieve reception capacities in the Eurodistrict of Strasbourg-Ortenau. That is why I repeat my request of 7 September, which the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance endorsed two days later: in Strasbourg, 220 000 square metres of Parliament buildings are empty 300 days a year. Each of our 750 offices has its own toilet, shower and folding bed. Kitchens and canteens are fully functional. There is also a fitness room. The offices of parliamentary officials, which are also vacant, can be used for refugee counsellors and individual counselling services. Meeting rooms can be used for language teaching, training and information events. In the underground car parks, the delivered aid for the region could be stored. The temporary travel costs of staff and parliamentary officials can be used much more sensibly to care for the refugees. Mr President, here too, please apply the urgent paragraph of the Rules of Procedure!

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the proposal for a Council decision introducing interim measures in the field of international protection in favour of Italy, Greece and Hungary.  My voice is not a voice of opposition to migration or aid to refugees, but against how we are trying to solve this problem. In the solutions proposed by the European Commission, we do not go back to the source of these problems, but merely react to the effects. This is a mis logic that will not allow us to adequately help those in need. It is high time to stop pretending that there is no war in Syria, because that is the source and reason for the current migration. Secondly, we cannot look at the Union as a loose patch work of 28 countries, we must seal the external borders, or at least abide by the Dublin Agreements. I look forward to proposing more comprehensive and thoughtful solutions at the forthcoming European Council and the Council of the European Union.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the resolution tabled because I do not agree that the provisional one-off measure should become a permanent instrument of EU asylum policy. The debate on one-off assistance to Italy, Greece and Hungary is appropriate, but it should ideally result in a joint solidarity procedure, not a majority order. However, if we want to adopt longer-term solutions that take into account different aspects, the problem of mass immigration to Europe from Africa and the Middle East, I insist on following the ordinary legislative procedure. Today, the Dublin Regulation, which determines the procedure and responsibility of the Member States for the asylum process, is still in force. If this Regulation no longer corresponds to the new situation, it must be amended or replaced by another. To do this, there are proper legislative procedures that cannot be circumvented and made excuses for an emergency.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. The Commission's proposal which we voted on today must be indisputably supported. We must give an immediate response to these 120,000 people who come out of a war and still have to go through a tough test until they reach Europe. Europe can and must welcome these 120,000 people and ensure their dignity and survival. We must demonstrate the pillars on which this Union has been based and share this responsibility in solidarity.  This is not the solution to the conflict in their places of origin, much less, but it is the solution for those 120,000 people who need our help. Europe must be more supportive in the toughest times. I hope that the Council will approve the proposal and that a unitary response will be given as quickly as possible to asylum seekers.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 My position on quotas does not change, so I could not support the Commission's proposal. I decided to abstain because I also took into account other measures which, although not part of the commission proposal, are being implemented in parallel by the Commission. I share these measures. These include the proposal for a European list of safe countries (for the more efficient handling of asylum applications by those who are indeed in danger of life), the publication of a handbook for a more effective return policy (for the faster return of those who have failed to apply for asylum), the creation of a Trust Fund for Africa (to support the creation of a more stable environment in African countries) and the creation of HotSpots (places for cooperation between the European Asylum Office, FRONTEX, EUROPOL and EUROJUSTU) that will allow for more effective registration of asylum seekers).

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Migrations are not a new problem – it's an undeniable fact. However, it is also a fact that the current crisis will not be solved by the measures proposed by the Council. These are ad hoc actions, calculated for the treatment of symptoms, not causes. These can only be removed in the place where this crisis was born, namely the Middle East and North Africa. There we must help the persecuted. That is where we should direct our efforts. There are real refugees who need our help. We will not change the direction in which immigrants are heading by administrative decision. Thousands of people travel to Germany and cross borders, not counting any regulations. They will not respect the order for forced relocation to other Member States. What will we do then to implement this resolution? Will we create closed camps, surround them with barbed wire, watch them day and night?  We saw yesterday images from Hungary, where the European Union's external border was stormed and pelted with stones. Do we want to see such images on our streets? This is the result of our induity for breaking the law and violating the principles on which the functioning of the Schengen area is based. Today's decision paves the way not only for the relocation of 120 000 migrants, but also for the next hundreds of thousands who will come here encouraged by our position. This is an irresponsible and dangerous resolution, the consequences of which we will have in the EU for many years to come.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: That concludes the explanations of vote.
